newsitem.title: GERMANY: INSTANT VIEW - Germany ind. orders rose in July.
newsitem.headline: INSTANT VIEW - Germany ind. orders rose in July.

text.p: Following are analysts' reactions to data on German industrial orders, which rose 0.6 percent in July from the prior month.
Consensus expectations were for a 0.3 percent rise.
Adolf Rosenstock, Industrial Bank of Japan, Frankfurt:
The figure is "a little better than I thought, but just barely. Looking at output and orders data, output was below expectations, so this compensates.
"The trend development is rather stable, so this should not have policy or market implications.
Rosenstock also said: "West Germany seems to have stabilised. We are on a moderate upward trend, but nothing spectacular. There is still ground to recover, as we are still below last year's levels.
"The improvement is there, but we are not out of the woods yet. In the east, there are clouds on the horizon.
"In east Germany, both output and orders were quite weak. It seems that east Germany is going through a difficult summer period. That is very disappointing, and points to more difficulties to come.
Gerhard Grebe, Bank Julius Baer in Frankfurt:
"At first glance the figures disappoint me, because I had expected a stronger number following last week's Ifo survey and machinery manufacture data.
"The 4.7 percent fall in east Germany may have missed large orders or have been caused by the holidays, but I expect it to be revised up.
"My outlook is for a strong economic recovery in the second quarter, followed by a continuation at a slower pace in the third quarter."
